questions.prompt: When a periodic signal passes through an LTI system, the output FS coefficients are:
options: D) Y_k = H(jω₀) · X_k (same H for all k)
questions.explanation: Each harmonic e^{jkω₀t} is an eigenfunction of the LTI system with eigenvalue H(jkω₀). By linearity, the output coefficient is Y_k = H(jkω₀)·X_k. Note: H is evaluated at different frequencies for each k.

questions.prompt: Complex exponentials e^{st} are called eigenfunctions of LTI systems because:
options: A) They have the highest energy
B) The output is a scaled version of the input: H(s)·e^{st}
D) They always produce zero output
questions.correctAnswer: B) The output is a scaled version of the input: H(s)·e^{st}
questions.explanation: An eigenfunction passes through the system and comes out as a scalar multiple of itself. For input e^{st}, output = H(s)·e^{st}. The shape is preserved; only the amplitude and phase change.

questions.prompt: The output of an LTI system to a periodic input is:
options: B) Periodic with a different period
C) Periodic with the same period T₀
questions.correctAnswer: C) Periodic with the same period T₀
questions.explanation: Each harmonic e^{jkω₀t} is scaled by H(jkω₀) but keeps the same frequency kω₀. So the output is a sum of the same harmonics with modified coefficients — still periodic with period T₀.

questions.prompt: Why does FS analysis convert convolution to multiplication?
options: A) Because the FS uses real functions
B) Because complex exponentials are eigenfunctions — each passes through independently
D) Because the input is always real
questions.correctAnswer: B) Because complex exponentials are eigenfunctions — each passes through independently
questions.explanation: Each basis function e^{jkω₀t} is an eigenfunction that passes through the system independently, getting scaled by H(jkω₀). No cross-terms between harmonics. This turns the convolution integral into simple multiplication: Y_k = H·X_k.

questions.prompt: A lowpass LTI system applied to a square wave will produce:
questions.explanation: A lowpass system attenuates high-frequency harmonics (|H(jkω₀)| decreases with k). The sharp edges of the square wave, which require high harmonics, get smoothed out. The output is a rounder version of the input.

questions.prompt: The output power when a periodic signal passes through an LTI system is:
questions.explanation: By Parseval's, P_out = Σ|Y_k|² = Σ|H(jkω₀)·X_k|² = Σ|H(jkω₀)|²·|X_k|². Each harmonic's power is scaled by |H|² at that frequency.

questions.prompt: If H(jω) = 1/(1+jωRC) and the input has ω₀ = 1, X₁ = 1, what is |Y₁|?
questions.explanation: |Y₁| = |H(jω₀)|·|X₁| = |1/(1+jRC)|·1 = 1/√(1+R²C²). The magnitude of H at ω = ω₀ scales the first harmonic's amplitude.

questions.prompt: Differentiation can be viewed as an LTI system with frequency response:
questions.explanation: d/dt of e^{jωt} = jω·e^{jωt}. So differentiation is an LTI system with H(jω) = jω — magnitude grows linearly (highpass). This unifies the differentiation property with the LTI framework.

questions.prompt: Integration can be viewed as an LTI system with frequency response:
questions.explanation: ∫e^{jωt}dt = (1/jω)e^{jωt}. Integration has H(jω) = 1/(jω) — magnitude decreases with ω (lowpass). This connects integration property to the LTI system perspective.

questions.prompt: An ideal lowpass filter with cutoff at 3ω₀ applied to a signal with 10 harmonics will:
options: A) Pass only harmonics k = 0, ±1, ±2, ±3 and block all higher ones
D) Only pass the DC component
questions.correctAnswer: A) Pass only harmonics k = 0, ±1, ±2, ±3 and block all higher ones
questions.explanation: An ideal lowpass with cutoff 3ω₀ sets H(jkω₀) = 1 for |k| ≤ 3 and H = 0 for |k| > 3. So Y_k = X_k for k = 0,±1,±2,±3 and Y_k = 0 for higher harmonics. The output is a band-limited approximation.
